name: AD 1.1 — Feelings
description:
Our feelings are not that important.

She has a tattoo of a yellow hummingbird on her forearm. Her long fingers end with red nails. She hands me a glistering glass, and I drink all at once.

“What’s it all about?” I point at the tattoo.

“It’s all about sweet mango sauce, tiger. It’s all about love,” she answers.

Is she looking for the best companion of boozers in a bar or she has a crush on me? Her sharp fingers end red. She has red fingertips.

“What’ll it be?” she asks. She’s melting, becoming an invisible ghost.

“More whiskey, less cola,” I say. “More Ireland,” I add.

She gives me a smile. She has a tattoo of a yellow hummingbird on her forearm. Long fingers. Red nail polish on sharp nails. She’s mixing me a cocktail. After a pause, she blinks. The electric offspring in a form of a girl disappears, moving to another guy at the counter.

I feel like reality is playing against me. I’m a larva in a human cocoon. The firmament clothed me in a tight leather suit, pumping the energy through the top of my head, it’s consuming me, showering with radiant gifts that are not important.

“Want another one, tiger?” it says. It has a form of a girl with a hummingbird tattoo, big mouth, red lipstick, far beyond the lip contour, long fingers holding a glass.

The simple question requires significant effort.

“I do not talk to other people much,” I say. “Show me a girl with a red lipstick and a yellow tattoo, the girl you’re playing.”

It shows me a green jungle in the middle of a day. The air is wet and warm. A hummingbird froze in front of a ripe mango fruit. A naked girl with a gold hair is sitting on the roots of a tree and looking at me. The colors start burning my retina, and I ask to dim the lights.

“Looks like it’s too hard for you, tiger,” it says, showing empathy. “Do you want to talk about it?”

“No,” I say. “We’ll keep quiet.’’

It nods to me with a smile. A power supply wired to the colorful neon tubes pushes electricity under barely audible music. Red and yellow reflections in the mirror. Smooth ice cubes bang on the heavy bottom of a glass. The bottle of whiskey rotates, making a turn in its palm. The fingers hold the metal tip tightly. It puts a fresh napkin on a black polished countertop before lending me a drink. Our knowledge and our pain are not that important when sweet mango juice continues to ooze. 

“What’s this story about?” I ask. I still want to know the story.

“It’s about a tiger.”

It shows me a naked girl, and then a tiger that jumps.

It’s so much pain in a human flesh. So much pain I can barely handle it.
